entry.title: AI-Powered Operational Excellence in Cloud ALM's Real User Monitoring
entry.content:
Introduction

In this blog we would discuss and get to know how the available Artificial Intelligence use cases can be activated and used in a customers landscape. There are various AI capability planned in SAP Cloud ALM, be it for Implementation or Operations space.

At present, specific to operations, Change point detection in Real User Monitoring is an AI feature a customer could leverage free of cost. In this blog we would discuss about "Change point detection in Real User Monitoring".

To Understand more about Real User Monitoring(RUM) please refer to https://support.sap.com/en/alm/sap-cloud-alm/operations/expert-portal/real-user-monitoring.html?anchorId=section

Cloud ALM Expert Portal for operations is a one stop solution for all your Operations related asks in Cloud ALM. https://support.sap.com/en/alm/sap-cloud-alm/operations/expert-portal.html

Change Point detection in Real User Monitoring(RUM)

Expert Portal for Operation defines Real User Monitoring as:

The purpose of Real User Monitoring is to provide transparency about the usage (executions) and the performance (response times) of user interactions. It supports the monitoring request executions from different platforms with a unified user experience using a common look-and-feel and handling pattern.

The basic concept is to get all user interactions and the relevant server requests which are the correlated in the Real User Monitoring application. Request executions are rated not based on fixed thresholds but on historical values.

Real User Monitoring shall help IT users and Business users to understand how often applications are executed and what is the response times for the end-users.

What is Change Point detection:

A change point for a request name signifies a notable performance shift compared to the recent past, lasting for a brief period (not just single executions). Such a change point might suggest an event that warrants closer examination.

How to activate Change Point Detection.

  1. Select Real User Monitoring card available under Operations area of SAP Cloud ALM. If you do not see RUM card, please make sure to have required authorization added to your user.

2. Make sure that data collection for the supported system is enabled.

3. Click on the system for which you want to activate ‚ÄúChange Point Detection‚Äú.

4.Activate the Change point Detection by enabling the toggle button and click on Save.

5.To see the notable performance shift compared to the recent past, on the left hand side click on Change Points.

6.Change Points are higlighted as shown in below image. Click on the Triangle to get more information about the detected change point.

7.Details about the change point.

8.You can navigate to the request using Display Requests button.

Additional Information

1. You get the option to exclude Application from this Change Point detection activation. Go to Change Point detection and then go to Excluded Applications(Custom). Click on + button to Add an entry.

2.Tab Excluded Applications(SAP managed) provide the list of applications which are excluded from this Change Point Detection.

entry.title: Re: Failed to load catalogs on App Finder page in FLP
entry.content:
I recently faced the same issue with the error "Failed to load catalogs" on the App Finder page in the Fiori Launchpad (FLP). In my case, the root cause was that the user was missing a basic Fiori authorization role.

I followed the steps below to resolve it

  • Go to transaction SU01
  • Enter the affected user ID 
  • Switch to the Roles tab
  • Add the role Z_FIORI_FOUNDATION_USER

Save the changes and ask the user to log out and log back in (if needed).

entry.title: Re: In Freight Pricing Condition what is the difference b...
entry.content:
The screen shot is not from OBYC but from M/08. In SAP MM-FI integration the mapping of a condition type to ‚ÄúAccount‚Äù and ‚ÄúAccrual‚Äù keys happens in your purchasing pricing procedure, which you maintain in transaction M/08. So, coming to two columns,

  • Account (left): the TRNx that posts your freight expense account
  • Accrual (right): the TRNx that posts your freight clearing (accrual) account

Goods Receipts in MM trigger only the accrual TRNx. SAP treats freight on GR as a provisional liability (you haven‚Äôt been invoiced yet), so it posts to the clearing account you assigned under the Accrual column. The ‚ÄúAccount‚Äù TRNx isn‚Äôt used until invoice verification.

The Standard Posting Flow for Freight on PO is you do a Goods Receipt (GR), System picks the TRNx in your Accrual column (e.g. KZxx or whatever you‚Äôve set) and posts a liability to your Freight Clearing GL., No posting to your Freight Expense account yet. You do an Invoice Receipt (MIRO), so that system looks at the TRNx in your Account column (e.g. KON) for freight and posts: ‚Äì Debit Freight Expense (Account TRNx) ‚Äì Credit Freight Clearing (Accrual TRNx). That way your GR/IR accrual is cleared and the true expense hits P&L when the vendor invoice arrives.

SAP doesn‚Äôt support posting freight expense at GR out‚Äêof‚Äêthe‚Äêbox. Freight is always treated as accrual on GR. To force expense at GR you‚Äôd have to build a small user‚Äêexit/BAdI to swap in the Account TRNx during GR (not standard practice) Or reverse the GR FI doc and re‚Äêpost manually in a single step (high-maintenance). Neither approach is recommended because it breaks the standard three‚Äêway match and accrual logic.

entry.title: Re: Leveraging SAP SuccessFactors Compensation for Salary Benchmarking
entry.content:
hi @hrajkumar 

Have you ever integrated the flow of Pay Ranges from an external provider like Aon or Mercer to EC Pay Ranges ? 

Not sure we'd want to position a custom MDF to store Pay Ranges since we can do so much already with the standard ones and with custom MDF we lose the ability to use the Compa Ratio and Range Penetration standard fields in Comp Info.

Sometimes we need to create additional custom fields in Comp Info portlet to store pay range min - mid - max points for the purpose of showing them on self-service comp statements generated through Document Generation but I believe we can build a business rule to get the values from the Pay Range object directly.

In Comp templates when worksheets are integrated with EC Pay Ranges we can pull the min-mid-max values in separate fields called payGuideMin, payGuideMid, payguideMax and them show them on comp module statements but that's not something we can do with Document Generation can do unfortunately which is the reason for these custom fields.

All the best,
Xavier

entry.title: SAP BTP AI Best Practices: Your Ultimate Guide for Building AI Solutions
entry.content:
As AI becomes a driving force in business innovation, developers need clear, proven patterns to turn ideas into enterprise-grade applications. That‚Äôs where SAP BTP AI Best Practices come in‚Äîa curated collection of implementation guidelines that connect powerful AI capabilities (like summarization, classification, and anomaly detection) with scalable, real-world solutions on SAP Business Technology Platform.

These BTP AI Best Practices are accessible from the Discovery Center, to get more details you can check SAP BTP Guidance Framework and the SAP BTP Guidance Framework - Introduction Post.

By turning advanced AI concepts into practical building blocks, SAP BTP AI Best Practices bring clarity, consistency, and momentum to your AI journey‚Äîso you can focus on creating impact, not reinventing the wheel. Our goal is to accelerate your development, reduce complexity, and unlock new possibilities with AI on SAP BTP.

To help developers navigate this landscape, the SAP BTP AI Best Practices website offers a central hub of essential resources‚Äîstructured around two complementary perspectives:

  • The functional view serves as a catalogue of frequently recurring AI use-case patterns. Each includes clear descriptions, hands-on examples, and thought-provoking questions to help you generate new ideas.
  • The technical view organizes best practices by AI domains, such as generative AI, and links them to their applicable capabilities. This structure helps you explore the underlying technologies and how they solve real-world business challenges.

Explore SAP BTP AI Best Practices

Below is a quick overview of the six best practices currently published, all of which focus on Generative AI use cases:

  • Access to Generative AI Models: Establishes a secure, flexible integration between SAP BTP and foundation models. It addresses how to manage model access, API calls, and infrastructure concerns while maintaining enterprise compliance.
  • Prompt Templating: Describes how to structure prompts dynamically using templates that incorporate user input and contextual business data. This ensures LLM responses remain relevant and tailored to specific enterprise use cases.
  • Data Masking: Shows how to protect sensitive or personal data when using external LLMs by applying masking techniques before sending prompts. This is essential for maintaining data privacy and regulatory compliance in enterprise applications.
  • Content Filtering: Focuses on ensuring safe, high-quality LLM outputs by filtering out inappropriate, irrelevant, or non-compliant responses before presenting them to end users.
  • Vector-based RAG: Embedding Pipeline: Covers the preprocessing steps needed to convert enterprise content into vector embeddings, including data chunking and storage strategies using SAP HANA Cloud‚Äôs vector engine.
  • Vector-based RAG: Query Pipeline: Explains how to retrieve and rank relevant vectorized content during a query, enabling Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) for more accurate, grounded, and context-aware LLM responses.

Building AI solutions in an enterprise context can be complex. Developers often face challenges like how to safely use external models, protect sensitive data, ensure response quality, and connect AI outputs to real business context. These best practices solve those issues with clear, repeatable approaches ‚Äî making it easier to build secure, relevant, and compliant AI features on SAP BTP.

These assets save time, reduce risk, and bring clarity to AI development. Instead of starting from scratch, teams can rely on proven patterns that work within the SAP BTP environment. They make it easier to go from idea to implementation, helping developers build smarter, faster, and with more confidence ‚Äî all while following enterprise standards.

You Might Also be Interested In

If you're looking to go deeper into AI development on SAP BTP, there are several resources to help you get started and stay current. From guided learning paths to hands-on missions and expert webinars, these materials complement the SAP BTP AI Best Practices and provide practical insights for your next project:

  1. SAP BTP AI Best Practices
  2. SAP Business AI Community
  3. SAP Developers Youtube channel

Feedback on SAP BTP AI Best Practices can be provided here.

Stay Tuned

This blog post is part of our ongoing series, Exploring the SAP BTP Guidance Framework, where we spotlight key resources that help you build smarter, faster, and with more confidence on SAP BTP. In the next post, we‚Äôll continue diving into different areas of the framework‚Äîso stay tuned and follow along as we explore more ways to turn ideas into enterprise-grade solutions.

entry.title: Re: Capacity Scheduling Table: no select all button
entry.content:
In the standard Capacity Scheduling Table app of S/4HANA 2022 (on-premise), SAP only delivers a Deselect All function‚Äîthere is no separate Select All button. That‚Äôs by design in this release.

However, you still have two quick ways to ‚Äúselect all‚Äù without an explicit button:

  • Use the Default Behavior; that is when you first enter the app or after a ‚ÄúDeselect All,‚Äù all visible rows are selected by default. You only ever need to click Deselect to clear, and the system will re-select everything the next time you load or refresh the app.
  • Shift-Click to Multi-Select; Click the checkbox of the first order you want, then hold Shift and click the checkbox of the last order in the list. SAP‚Äôs Fiori table control will automatically select every order in between. This mimics a ‚ÄúSelect All‚Äù over any contiguous range.

entry.title: Re: How to add calculation field and code in Custom CDS view
entry.content:
Hello Grace,

Can you please check whether the following information provides the help you're looking for? (GenAI was used to help generate this content.)

To add a calculation field in a Custom CDS view, you can use the expression editor to define your calculation. Here‚Äôs a step-by-step guide on how to write the code for your specific requirement:

Steps to Add Calculation:

  1. Open the Custom CDS Views App: Navigate to the ‚ÄòCustom CDS Views‚Äô app in your SAP S/4HANA Cloud environment.

  2. Select Your CDS View: Choose the CDS view where you want to add the calculation.

  3. Add a Calculation: Click on ‚ÄòAdd‚Äô and select ‚ÄòCalculation‚Äô. Extend and Integrate Your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Adding Calculations

  4. Define the Calculation: Use the expression editor to define your calculation. You can use fields from the underlying data sources and apply arithmetic operations. Extend and Integrate Your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Calculations

  5. Write the Code:

    • Use a conditional statement to check the Debit/Credit code.
    • If the Debit/Credit code is ‚ÄòH‚Äô, multiply the quantity by -1.

    Here is an example of how you might write this in the expression editor:

    CASE WHEN DebitCreditCode = 'H' THEN Quantity * (-1) ELSE Quantity END

  6. Save and Publish: Once you have defined your calculation, save and publish the CDS view.

Additional Information:

  • You can use arithmetic and logical expressions in your calculations.
  • Built-in functions are available for more complex calculations.
Extend and Integrate Your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Adding Calculations
Extend and Integrate Your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Calculations

Kind regards,

Henrike

entry.title: Re: withholding Tax Report for Country - Nigeria (Activat...
entry.content:
In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, there is no country-specific, pre-packaged ‚ÄúNigeria Withholding Tax‚Äù report out of the box. Instead, you leverage the Generic Withholding Tax Report framework and then tailor it for Nigeria.

The CLT Tool activation sets up tax jurisdiction and extended WHT in your system, but does not deliver a tailored Excel/ALV report for Nigeria. Instead, the Generic Withholding Tax Report is the standard mechanism. No separate ‚ÄúNG-specific‚Äù report tile exists.

SAP delivers a configurable ALV report category GENC_WHT that captures extended withholding-tax line items and groups them by org unit, business partner, tax type, and tax code. Open the Fiori app Setting Up Your Statutory Reporting. Under Report Category Assignments, create or edit an entry:

  • Assign Report Category ID = GENC_WHT
  • Country/Region = NG (Nigeria)
  • Reporting Entity = (your company code or business place). Save your configuration.

Launch the Fiori app Run Generic Withholding Tax Report, select your Company Code (or Business Place), enter the Reporting Date (period), choose whether to include Supplier WHT or Customer WHT, Filter by supplier/customer which is optional, tax type, tax code. The system will output all extended-WHT documents for Nigeria in the chosen period.

entry.title: Re: withholding Tax Report for Country - Nigeria (Activat...
entry.content:
Hi @gautam_SAP 

Thank you for clarifying your setup and efforts.

The SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud documentation for release 2508 confirms that there is no standard Tax Withholding Report specific to Nigeria currently delivered despite activating Nigeria country settings via the CLT tool.

SAP's standard withholding tax reporting functionality is available for a defined set of countries, but Nigeria is not included in that list as of version 2508. Therefore, even though Nigeria is activated in your country configuration, no prebuilt report exists for generating withholding tax data specifically for Nigeria.

What you try as an alternative:

Build a custom report using CDS views or ABAP on SAP BTP that extracts needed withheld tax data for Nigeria. Or explore third-party solutions or SAP partners for country-specific withholding tax reporting if compliance requires it.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

Please note, even if your custom field is not marked mandatory, the SAP Migration Cockpit still requires a value in the template if the field exists.

Here is what I suggest you do:

  • If the custom field is in the template, ensure that each row includes a value.
  • Alternatively, you can remove the column from the template if it‚Äôs not needed.

entry.title: Re: The return to vendor PO with consignment stock and it...
entry.content:
In ECC, the Purchasing document‚Äôs Shipping tab only appears when the PO/item category is configured as shipping-relevant. By design, Item Category K (consignment stock return) is not delivery‚Äêrelevant in SAP‚Äôs standard IMG, so the Shipping tab is suppressed. In an EWM‚Äêmanaged scenario you do not need to maintain shipping data on the PO‚ÄîEWM controls outbound delivery creation itself.

If you use Warehouse Management or ERP outbound delivery (VL01N) to physically ship stock back, the PO must be delivery-relevant. You‚Äôd then see the Shipping tab on the PO, and data there (route, shipping condition, Incoterms, etc.) drives the ERP delivery.

EWM creates its own Outbound Delivery for the return-to-vendor PO. All shipping instructions live in the EWM Delivery Type customizing (SPRO ‚Üí Extended WM ‚Üí Outbound Process ‚Üí Define / Assign Delivery Types). The PO‚Äôs Shipping tab isn‚Äôt used by EWM at all, so SAP hides it on Category K by default.

Best Practice in EWM would be Keep Item Category K non‚Äêdelivery-relevant in ECC. Rely on EWM Delivery Types (and your EWM Integration Model) to handle return deliveries. Maintain shipping instructions (e.g. packing, route determination) in EWM customizing under: Extended Warehouse Management ‚Üí Outbound Process ‚Üí Shipping Data ‚Üí Define Delivery Types. By leaving the Shipping tab off the PO and leveraging EWM‚Äôs delivery setup, you avoid double‚Äêmaintenance and ensure that return-to-vendor stock flows correctly through your warehouse.

entry.title: Re: How to hide inactive plants from LOV in standard SAP...
entry.content:
Hi @JasClemencio 

Thank you for the question.

Unfortunately, SAP does not provide a standard option to exclude inactive plants directly from the value help.

However, I suggest you consider the following workarounds:

  • You have the possibility to limit visibility by assigning roles using object M_PLANT. This will not hide the values in the dropdown, but it will prevent users from running reports for unauthorized plants.
  • It is also possible to enhance the standard F4 help using BADIs or exits to filter out specific plants like MY21, MY22, etc.
  • You can prefix inactive plants with something like "ZZ_". That can help you easily recognize and avoid them.
  • You can add warning messages or validations during selection can help guide you away from inactive entries.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Need help with SP_TransactionNotification
entry.content:
Hello, 

You don't need to check the UserSign field from the table, but rather the new parameter user_id (ID of the user currently logged in to SAP Business One).

ALTER PROCEDURE SBO_SP_TransactionNotification
(
in object_type nvarchar(30), -- SBO Object Type
in transaction_type nchar(1), -- [A]dd, [U]pdate, [D]elete, [C]ancel, C[L]ose
in num_of_cols_in_key int,
in list_of_key_cols_tab_del nvarchar(255),
in list_of_cols_val_tab_del nvarchar(255),
in user_id int

entry.title: Re: Standard Message type for the Inbound IDOC 944 for Po...
entry.content:
To post goods receipts (PGR) against HU-based Inbound Deliveries (IBDs) and update the delivery/Goods Movement status via an incoming EDI 944, you should use one of the EWM-specific IDoc types rather than MBGMCR, DESADV or WMBBXY.

/SCWM/IDOC_GR or /SCWM/IDOC_GI are the two message types are delivered with EWM and are designed to handle HU-based IBDs. They carry full HU structure, update the IBD‚Äôs goods‚Äêmovement status, and set the HU statuses in one step.

Configuration steps would be in WE20, add your 3PL as partner, assign message type /SCWM/IDOC_GR (or /SCWM/IDOC_GI) and link to the appropriate basic type. In BD64, include the EWM logical system for inbound. Activate inbound processing for these IDocs under SPRO ‚Üí Extended Warehouse Management ‚Üí Interfaces ‚Üí EDI ‚Üí Inbound IDoc ‚Üí Configure Message Types. Map the 944 fields (quantities, HU numbers, dates) to the IDoc segments in an ALE mapping project.

What happens is when SAP receives /SCWM/IDOC_GR, function modules like /SCWM/IDOC_PROCESS_GR process the IDoc, post the GR, and update the IBD lines and HU statuses. This approach is fully standard and has been adopted by other customers posting HU-based GRs via IDoc.

The next option is to go with SHPCON which is the Shipping Confirmation IDoc, originally intended for confirming PIC (packing) and PGI events. You can repurpose SHPCON to confirm a PGR by setting the qualifier fields for PGI (PMI) in segment E1EDT18.

Configuration steps would be in WE20, configure your 3PL partner with message type SHPCON and basic type DELVRY03. In BD64, add your EWM system. No further SPRO customizing is required‚ÄîEWM‚Äôs inbound IDoc handler for SHPCON will update the IBD status. The key benefit is you leverage an already-released IDoc type to update both the HU‚Äê and delivery‚Äêlevel GR status without custom coding. Several implementations use SHPCON for PGR‚Äîjust map your EDI 944 to SHPCON segments (PIC vs. PGI indicators) and let EWM update the delivery

entry.title: Re: Which is the bandwidth recommended between customer c...
entry.content:
Hi @AndersonCM 

According to the guidance on bandwidth requirements for connecting to RISE with SAP, there is no official SAP Note or document specifies an exact required bandwidth. However, SAP typically recommends 1 Mbps per user as a general guideline, depending on usage patterns. Note that, connectivity to RISE usually involves VPN, ExpressRoute, SD-WAN, or VNet peering, depending on the hyperscaler.

I suggest you raise a ticket to SAP directly during your onboarding to help you validate bandwidth needs for your specific use case.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Chris

entry.title: SAP Cloud - Multiple Delivery addresses in Purchase Order
entry.content:
Dear community, 

our client is on SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public Edition.

We are facing the following challenge: We have 1 storage location but 6-8 different delivery points within the same storage location. We need the delivery address to be entered in the Purchase Order and print it on the PO form so that the supplier can send the goods to the right place.

As per standard, the delivery address in the PO is taken from the storage location (SLOC Configuration) - and we can maintain only one address for the SLOC in customizing. Of course, one possibility is to create an address table entry for each delivery point. The purchase could enter the address number during  PO creation. But that would mean that the PO creator has manual work: the right address needs to be entered n in each PO...

Does anyone have any idea to avoid or at least minimize the manual efforts?

Thanks and regards,

entry.title: Re: Local currency type not showing in finsc_ledger
entry.content:
When currency type 10 (‚ÄúCompany Code Currency‚Äù) isn‚Äôt selectable for a given company code in FINSC_LEDGER, it means it hasn‚Äôt been assigned in your ledger‚Äìcompany-code settings. You must explicitly map currency type 10 to your company code (PKCO) for the ledger in question. Follow these steps:

Execute transaction FINSC_LEDGER, select your Ledger (e.g. 0L for leading ledger) and click Details. From the menu, choose Company Code Settings for Ledger.In the pop-up, locate company code PKCO (add it if missing). In the ‚ÄúCurrency Types‚Äù column, add 10 so it reads:

  • 00 (Document)
  • 10 (Company Code / Local)

Save your entries. After this, currency type 10 will be active (not greyed-out) for PKCO in FINSC_LEDGER.

Please note the Key consideration here is Currency type 10 and 00 are SAP-predefined; you cannot remove or rename them, only assign them at company-code level. If PKCO belongs to a controlling area with multiple company codes, ensure all share a consistent controlling-area currency in OKKP. Inconsistencies there can prevent assignment of type 10.

thanks for raising your question in the community

For your scenario is see the challenge to pick only Billing Document Requests (BDR) only for Service Contracts. That means, you need to make sure that no BDR from Service Orders, Service Confirmations, or Professional Services.

I propose the following set-up of your job:

entry.title: Re: Import connection from FSM with SAC.
entry.content:
Hi @KUMARSURYASAI_KOTA42 

Thank you for your question.
Unfortunately, SAC‚Äôs OData query builder doesn‚Äôt currently support direct range filters. The User Interface only allows ‚ÄúEqual to‚Äù or ‚ÄúExcept‚Äù options. As a workaround, we can either run multiple filtered imports using specific ID values or define filtered views on the FSM side if possible.

SAC has a soft cap of 100K records per import. To enable you handle larger datasets, I would suggest you split the load into smaller batches using the available filters, also ensure the FSM OData service supports pagination. If volumes grow significantly, you may consider a middleware e.g., CPI or SAP Data Intelligence to streamline your process.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: SAP Cloud - Multiple Delivery addresses in Purchase O...
entry.content:
Yes you are right; by design a PO in Public Cloud only picks up a single address per storage location, so you must do extra work to support multiple ‚Äúdelivery points.‚Äù Below are the main approaches you can use to minimize manual entry:

Maintain each delivery point as an extra address on your vendor‚Äôs BP record. Use the Manage Business Partner Addresses Fiori app to add 6‚Äì8 addresses under your supplier.
In the PO‚Äôs Delivery Address tab, a field ‚ÄúAddress Reference‚Äù lets you pick one of those BP addresses. Address numbers are generated when you enter a free-text address and save (or when you maintain them via the BP app). Once they exist, you can select the address number instead of typing the full street/block each time. But here, one drawback is, in the Create Purchase Order app, you cannot yet search or drop-down those address numbers. You can only key them in.

To avoid manual typing of the address number, you can use the Cloud‚Äôs Custom Logic (BAdI) framework:

In the Custom Business Objects (CBO) app, create a Custom Logic for the business object PurchaseOrder (BO Business Object: PurchaseOrder). Implement the ‚ÄúBefore Save‚Äù hook to Read the PO‚Äôs Plant (or custom ‚ÄúDelivery Point‚Äù field you add), Look up your BP‚Äôs address table (via the standard CDS or API) to find the matching address number. Populate the PO item‚Äôs AddressReference property with that number. The end result would be when end users create or change a PO in the Create PO or Manage PO app, the system auto-fills the correct address number for them. They only override if absolutely necessary.

entry.title: Re: SAP table PTRV_VENDOR_SYNC different S4Coreop 106 and...
entry.content:
In S/4HANA 106 and earlier, the table PTRV_VENDOR_SYNC (in component FI-TV) held all the Travel‚ÄêManagement‚Äìdriven settings for synchronizing HR infotype data into a vendor master, including block/unblock rules, reference vendor/Business Partner, bank‚ÄêID overrides, tax-category sourcing, etc. In S/4HANA 108 these controls have been refactored into the Business Partner framework‚Äîand the old table is replaced by the generic Synchronized HR Data to Supplier/Customer customizing.

All the ‚Äúmissing‚Äù settings now live under the Business Partner SPRO node‚Äîinstead of Travel Management. Open SPRO ‚Üí Cross-Application Components ‚Üí SAP Business Partner ‚Üí Basic Settings ‚Üí Synchronization of HR Data with Supplier/Customer. Within that activity, you‚Äôll find sub‚Äênodes for

  • General Settings (defines CC, roles, BP grouping, reference BP)
  • Block/Unblock Rules (defines block indicator, block days and unblock logic)
  • Bank Determination (maps HR infotype-bank subtypes to BP bank-ID 1 & 2)
  • Tax Number Sourcing (maps infotype17 or other sources to BP tax category/number)

Whenever you transport these nodes, the system writes into the replaced table (now called something like /TM/VENDORSYNC in the background) and drives the new Business-Partner‚Äìbased synchronization.

To see the underlying table, go to SE11, search for the DDIC structure TM_VENDORSYNC or TM_BP_SYNC. You‚Äôll discover fields like BP_ROLE, BLOCK_IND, BLOCK_DAYS, REF_BUPA, BANK_TYPE1, BANK_TYPE2, TAXCAT, TAXSOURCE. This is the new ‚Äútable behind the scenes‚Äù that replaces PTRV_VENDOR_SYNC.

You can read the Official Documentation by going to the S/4HANA 108 Help Library ‚Üí ‚ÄúBusiness Partner‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúBasic Settings‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúSynchronization of HR Data.‚Äù

entry.title: Re: Budget exceeds error through ko88 on some IO.

entry.title: Re: Budget exceeds error through ko88 on some IO.
entry.content:
Before any settlement posting is created, the system runs a budget check (availability control). By default, it sums:

  • Actuals (CO postings)
  • Commitments (purchase orders, requisitions,schedules)
  • Planned settlements (costs that will be settled in this KO88 run)

Even if your order has zero actuals, it might still have commitments or be slated to receive costs via settlement from other orders. That ‚Äúwould-be‚Äù settled value is pulled into the check‚Äîand can tip you over the budget limit.

Some common reasons why you get Budget errors on "Empty" orders are

Order is a Settlement Receiver If other orders use your order as a receiver in their settlement rules (check in KO04 for ‚ÄúReceiver = Internal Order‚Äù), KO88 in collective run mode will plan to settle their costs to yours‚Äîand include that planned amount in the availability check.

Open Commitments Purchase orders or requisitions account-assigned to the order consume budget under the ‚Äúcommitment‚Äù ledger. Use the Fiori app ‚ÄúManage Internal Order Budgets‚Äù or report S_ALR_87013019 (Budget/Actual/Commitments) to see these.

Statistical Re-postings (Asset Settlements) If your order is used in Asset Accounting (AuC), the settlement to AuC and the subsequent statistical repost back to the order (via ACSET customizing) can re-debit the order‚Äîwithout leaving a visible CO document line in KOB1‚Äîand drive you into an overrun.


To diagnose this,
Check Settlement Rules ‚Äì Transaction KO04 ‚Üí Enter your order ‚Üí Display ‚Üí Settlement rule ‚ÄúReceiver‚Äù tab. ‚Äì Is the order listed as a receiver for other orders?

Check Commitments ‚Äì Run S_ALR_87013019 or use KOB2 for plan line items. ‚Äì Look for commitments > 0 against that order.

Simulate Availability Check ‚Äì Go to SPRO ‚Üí Controlling ‚Üí Internal Orders ‚Üí Budgeting & Avail. Control ‚Üí Availability Control in Settlement ‚Üí Choose ‚ÄúTest Availability Control‚Äù for your order and date. ‚Äì You‚Äôll see exactly which components (actual, planned, commit¬≠ments) are triggering the block.


To fix this

Exclude Receiver Orders from Collective Run On the KO88 selection screen, uncheck ‚ÄúCollective Run‚Äù or use variant settings so only orders with actual postings get picked up.

Adjust Tolerance Limits SPRO ‚Üí Controlling ‚Üí Internal Orders ‚Üí Budgeting & Avail. Control ‚Üí Define Tolerance Limits for Availability Control. Increase tolerance or turn the error into a warning.

Remove Statistical Re-debits In ACSET, deselect the ‚ÄúAccntAssgnmt‚Äù flag for the relevant movement types so assets don‚Äôt re-debit the order after settlement.

Clear Up Commitments Release or close purchase requisitions/POs tied to the order, or shift their account assignment away, so they no longer consume budget.

entry.title: Re: Unable to see list data when I run the app
entry.content:
Hello @Ankita_Mundhra 

If you're using SAP Build Apps (or AppGyver):

Your integration query already fetches data successfully.

The issue lies in how that data is being linked to your UI, not the query itself.

As long as your data variable is correctly set to autoload and the UI is properly bound to that variable, the data should display.

Please double-check below

Is the data variable set to autoload?
If not, set it to autoload or use page logic to trigger it.

Is the UI element (e.g., table or list) bound to the data variable ‚Äî not the query?
Must be bound to the data variable, not the integration directly.

Is the data structure correct and accessible?
Use a temporary text element:{{ JSON.stringify(yourDataVariable) }}

This shows what‚Äôs actually in the variable during runtime.

Let me know if it works

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: freight-cost-condition divided per position in outbound delivery the same as at sales documents.
entry.content:
For example situation now : 

ZFRE= our freight-condition. | ZFRE= 10 euro. 

So order situation:

Product X | 2 pieces | 10 euro p/piece | therefore : ZFRE = 10/25*20 = 8 euro. 

  • 10 = ZFRE-freight. 
  • 25 comes from 10+10+5 total document costs.
  • 20=10+10 this position.

Product Y | 1 piece | 5 euro p/piece | therefore : ZFRE = 10/25*5 = 2 euro. 

  • 10 = ZFRE-freight. 
  • 25 comes from 10+10+5 total document costs.
  • 5= this position.

first outbound delivery / billing document:

Product X with 1 less piece:

Product X | 1 pieces | 10 euro | therefore : ZFRE = 10/25*10 = 4 euro. 

Product Y | 1 piece | 5 euro | therefore : ZFRE = 10/25*5 = 2 euro. 

SAP waits for next outbound deliveries for further ZFRE of 10-4-2=4 euro on position 1. 

--------------------------------------------------

Question: how to:

order situation same:

Product X | 2 pieces | 10 euro p/piece | therefore : ZFRE = 10/25*20 = 8 euro. 

Product Y | 1 piece | 5 euro p/piece | therefore : ZFRE = 10/25*5 = 2 euro. 

first delivery/billing document:

Product X with 1 piece on position 1 : 

Product X | 1 pieces |10 euro | ZFRE = 10/15*10 = 6.67 euro. 

Product Y | 1 piece |5 euro | ZFRE=10/15*5 = 3.33 euro. 

 

So we want:

At first delivery we want the 10 euro freight divided but calculated based on positions at outbound delivery. Next upcoming deliveries are then without freight costs because it is already payed. How could we do this ?

entry.title: How to Count Table Entries with a Custom KPI
entry.content:
With custom KPIs in Business Process Monitoring, you can enrich the application with further KPIs tailored to your needs. 

SAP Cloud ALM: Business Process Monitoring

This blog will explain how custom KPIs in Business Process Monitoring in SAP Cloud ALM can be used to count entries in a table.
It is a simple example, aiming to inspire what's in and what you could do.

 

General Information

The general process for a custom KPI is as follows:

Process Flow: Custom KPIs

The process for custom KPIs starts with their definition, followed by general and KPI-specific steps, and ends with using custom KPIs.

And in addition, the detailed flow for custom KPI for an ABAP-based component, which we will now follow:

Process Flow: Custom KPI for ABAP-based components

If you would like to learn more about custom KPIs, our Expert Portal (Custom KPIs) and the SAP Help Portal (Custom KPIs) are amazing places to go to. 

 

Before you Begin

Here are three things that are relevant before you can start:

  • In order to use a custom KPI for an ABAP-based component, the respective setup for Business Process Monitoring needs to be completed, and active, successful data collection is needed. You can find all relevant details on the Expert Portal: Custom KPIs - Prerequisites and Setup 
  • To define a custom KPI, you need to have the role of Process Monitoring Administrator
  • For the instrumentation of the KPI, bring some ABAP development knowledge

Let's get started with some context.

 

Context

We will create a custom KPI for ABAP-based components. As data model - tables for which we will count entries the famous sflight model.

As a result, the following queries shall be covered by the KPI:

  1. Total number of flights
  2. Number of flights operated with a 737-800
  3. Number of single flight bookings
  4. Number of flights that are scheduled
  5. Number of flights operated with a 777-300

Let's follow the steps mentioned above.

 

Steps for a Custom KPI

The following section will guide you through the process that results in a custom KPI. In the section "Use Custom KPI", you can also find examples of events based on the counters above. 

 

A) General Business Process Monitoring Steps

In order to use a custom KPI for an ABAP-based component, the respective setup for Business Process Monitoring needs to be completed, and active, successful data collection is needed.

You can find all relevant details on the Expert Portal: Custom KPIs - Prerequisites and Setup 

 

B) Custom KPI Definition

As this example will offer all checks collectively in a single KPI, this is how the KPI is defined:

Technical IDLabel
IDID
Field1Check No
Field2Table
Field3Number of Entries
Field4 Additional Criteria 1
Field5  Additional Criteria 2
Field6Label
TIMESTAMP_UTCTimestamp

In the Business Process Monitoring application

  • Open the configuration panel
  • Expand the sections Managed Components > KPI Management
  • Choose Configure KPIs
  • In the KPI Management, choose + to Create a Custom KPI

For information and characteristics, specify the relevant details ‚Äì in our example

InformationCharacteristics
Name: Flight Counters
Description: Flight Counters
KPI ID: ZKPITA0999
Category: Backlog
Data Collection Frequency: 15 Minutes		FIELD_1 Check No
FIELD_2 Table
FIELD_3 Number of Entries
FIELD_4 Additional Criteria 1
FIELD_5 Additional Criteria 2
FIELD_6 Label 

Result:

Business Process Monitoring: KPI Definition

 

C) Instrument KPI

The following steps show the instrumentation in the managed component and require ABAP development knowledge:

  • Create a subclass of /SDF/CL_CRBPA_CKPI:
    Instrumentation: Class Properties
  • Redefine method GET_KPI_ID and GET_DATA:
    Instrumentation: Redefined Methods
    Instrumentation: Method GET_KPI_IDInstrumentation: Method GET_DATA

 

D) Auto-Discovery and Data Collection

These steps are taken care of automatically for you based on our framework.

No manual activities required - only giving it some time üòâ

 

E) Use Custom KPI

The result in the application looks as follows:

Business Process Monitoring: KPI Details

Let's proceed with the definition of an Event: to receive an email notification.

 

Define Event

What would be a KPI without an event or being alerted? Let's have a look at two examples, one for counter 2 and the second for counter 5.

Here is the definition for getting an alert if there are results for counter 2:
Business Process Monitoring: Event Definition Counter 2

And as you can see in the KPI details above, relevant entries are found - the resulting notification: 

Event: Notification

Similarly, you can also define an event for counter 5 - this looks as follows
Business Process Monitoring: Event Definition Counter 5

In this case, the expected result is no email. Currently, there is no flight in the data that is operated with 777-300. Once there is a respective data set, it will be identified as part of the next data collection, with this visible in the KPI details. Based on the event definition, an alert and email notification will be triggered. 

 

Summarizing

So let's summarize: this blog explains, based on an example, how to use a custom KPI to count table entries.

We chose the way, one single KPI that covers all counters. Many other options are possible. So it is now your turn to get started!

Happy to hear from you how you used it, so feel free to leave a comment below.

entry.title: Where can I start learning how to manage SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition implementations?
entry.content:
I recommend to access our Managing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition Projects   learning journey.

Overview
This Learning Journey is designed for experienced SAP professionals, including project managers, consultants, and technical leads, who seek to enhance their skills in managing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition implementations. It is particularly suited for individuals aspiring to advance their careers by taking on strategic, high-level roles in cloud-based project delivery and enterprise integration.

Learning objectives
Within this Learning Journey, SAP project managers can deepen their expertise of managing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition implementations, specifically focusing on SAP tools, methodologies, and SAP Business Suite portfolio.

This Learning Journey will lead to the certification "Managing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition Projects", which includes courses on the following subjects:

  1. Exploring SAP Activate - Implementation Tools and Methodology
  2. Implementing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  3. Discovering Organizational Change Management for SAP Cloud Projects
  4. Introducing the RISE with SAP Methodology for SAP Partners and Customers

Prerequisites

  • Project Management Experience: Minimum of 5‚Äì7 years managing ERP implementation projects, preferably SAP Cloud-related
  • SAP Expertise: Hands-on experience with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, including system deployment, configuration, and lifecycle management
  • Cloud Implementation Experience: Proven track record in managing cloud-based SAP projects, including understanding of SaaS models

Please post you question related to the digital learning Journey in the Q&A area. 
Our SAP Learning Experts will get back to you as soon as possible! 
We are here to support you.


I appreciate your feedback and we will make sure to continue sharing interesting topics.

entry.title: Have You Heard About Service Management Solutions from SAP?
entry.content:
How One Service Call Turned Into a Business Breakthrough

It started with a broken compressor on a hot summer day.

In the past, resolving a case like this would have meant a flurry of phone calls, digging through disconnected systems for warranty info, manually checking technician availability, and hoping the right spare part was in stock.

But not this time.

Thanks to SAP‚Äôs end-to-end Service Management solution, Anna‚Äôs team had everything they needed in one place‚Äîfrom customer contract details and installed base info to intelligent technician scheduling, mobile field execution, and real-time updates. Within hours, the right technician was on-site with the correct spare part. The issue was fixed before it became a crisis.

And the customer? Still a customer. More loyal than ever.

In today‚Äôs service economy, it‚Äôs no longer enough to sell great products. Customers expect fast, reliable, and proactive service. That‚Äôs where Service Management solutions from SAP come in‚Äîhelping companies like Anna‚Äôs turn every service interaction into a competitive advantage.

SAP connects the dots across your entire service lifecycle, from the initial request to billing and performance analysis. It‚Äôs not just about solving issues‚Äîit‚Äôs about transforming service into a strategic driver of growth, loyalty, and efficiency.

Why Do Customers Choose SAP?

Because SAP doesn‚Äôt just offer tools‚Äîit offers transformation.

From One Service Call to a Strategic Shift

Back to Anna: what started as one resolved breakdown evolved into a deeper realization. With SAP, her company didn‚Äôt just fix machines faster‚Äîthey started rethinking service delivery entirely. Today, they offer predictive maintenance packages, use data to improve uptime, and collaborate more closely with partners.

Service became more than a cost center. It became a value engine.
